titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dick family papers 1985.001
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham (2011); Updated by John Zarrillo (2014)
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:16:42 +0000.

did.abstract: The Dick Family papers span ther period 1848 to 1860 and measure 0.1 linear feet. The papers include correspondence, wills, deeds, mortgages, military records, clippings, and illustrations. Archibald L. Dick, engraver, Brooklyn, N.Y. (c. 1793-1856), was once a resident of 66 Fulton Street and his last residence was 157 Gold Street. James L. Dick (c. 1833-1868), an artist in Brooklyn, was Archibald Dick's son and also resided at 157 Gold Street. He was one of the founding members of the Brooklyn Art School and Academy of Design.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Archibald L. Dick, a Brooklyn engraver and one of the founding members of the Brooklyn Art School and Academy of Design, was once a resident of 66 Fulton Street. His last residence was 157 Gold Street, where James L. Dick (c. 1833-1868), an artist in Brooklyn and Archibald Dick's son, also resided.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Dick family papers, 1985.001, Box and Folder number; Center for Brooklyn History, Brooklyn Public Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dick Family papers span ther period 1848 to 1860 and measure 0.1 linear feet. The papers include correspondence, wills, deeds, mortgages, military records, clippings, and illustrations.
